content.quick_definition: Net Promoter Score (NPS) is a customer loyalty metric that measures how likely users are to recommend your documentation to others on a scale of 0-10. Documentation teams use NPS to gauge user satisfaction, identify content gaps, and prioritize improvements based on direct user feedback.
content.detailed_explanation:
Net Promoter Score (NPS) is a widely-adopted metric that helps documentation teams understand user satisfaction and loyalty by asking one simple question: "How likely are you to recommend this documentation to a colleague?" Users respond on a scale of 0-10, with scores categorized into Detractors (0-6), Passives (7-8), and Promoters (9-10).

Key Features

  • Simple single-question survey format that reduces user friction
  • Standardized 0-10 scale for consistent measurement across teams
  • Automatic categorization of responses into three user segments
  • Benchmarkable score calculation (% Promoters - % Detractors)
  • Optional follow-up questions for qualitative insights

Benefits for Documentation Teams

  • Quantifies user satisfaction with specific documentation sections
  • Identifies high-performing content that can be replicated
  • Reveals pain points requiring immediate attention
  • Provides data-driven justification for documentation investments
  • Tracks improvement trends over time
  • Enables comparison between different documentation formats or topics

Common Misconceptions

  • NPS alone provides complete user satisfaction insights (needs qualitative data)
  • All documentation should achieve the same NPS targets
  • Higher scores always indicate better documentation quality
  • NPS surveys should be deployed on every page or interaction

use_cases.title: API Documentation User Journey Optimization
use_cases.problem: Developers struggle with API documentation, leading to increased support tickets and delayed integrations
use_cases.solution: Deploy NPS surveys at key completion points in API documentation workflows to identify friction points
use_cases.implementation:
1. Add NPS widgets after code examples, authentication guides, and endpoint references
2. Segment responses by developer experience level and use case
3. Follow up with detractors to understand specific pain points
4. Track NPS trends as documentation improvements are implemented
use_cases.outcome: Improved developer experience, reduced support burden, and faster API adoption rates

use_cases.title: Knowledge Base Content Performance Measurement
use_cases.problem: Unable to determine which help articles are truly solving user problems versus just being visited frequently
use_cases.solution: Implement NPS scoring on help articles to measure satisfaction beyond page views and time-on-page metrics
use_cases.implementation:
1. Add NPS surveys to high-traffic help articles
2. Compare NPS scores with traditional metrics like bounce rate
3. Identify articles with high traffic but low NPS for revision
4. Use promoter feedback to understand what makes content exceptional
use_cases.outcome: Data-driven content strategy focusing on user satisfaction rather than just engagement metrics

use_cases.title: Onboarding Documentation Effectiveness Tracking
use_cases.problem: New users complete onboarding flows but struggle with product adoption, suggesting documentation gaps
use_cases.solution: Use NPS to measure satisfaction at each onboarding milestone and identify where users lose confidence
use_cases.implementation:
1. Deploy micro-NPS surveys after each onboarding section
2. Create cohort analysis comparing NPS scores to long-term user retention
3. A/B test different documentation approaches and measure NPS impact
4. Build feedback loops from low-scoring sections back to content creators
use_cases.outcome: Higher user activation rates and reduced churn during critical early-use periods

use_cases.title: Technical Documentation Accessibility Assessment
use_cases.problem: Documentation serves users with varying technical expertise, but it's unclear if content complexity matches audience needs
use_cases.solution: Segment NPS responses by user role and experience level to optimize content for different audiences
use_cases.implementation:
1. Include role and experience questions alongside NPS surveys
2. Analyze score variations between beginner, intermediate, and advanced users
3. Identify content that works well for all levels versus specialized content needs
4. Create user-specific documentation paths based on NPS insights
use_cases.outcome: Personalized documentation experiences that serve diverse user needs effectively

best_practices.title: Time NPS Surveys Strategically
best_practices.description: Deploy NPS surveys immediately after users complete meaningful documentation tasks rather than randomly or on page load
best_practices.do: Trigger surveys after task completion, successful code implementation, or problem resolution
best_practices.dont: Don't interrupt users mid-task or survey immediately upon page arrival before they've engaged with content

best_practices.title: Segment Responses for Actionable Insights
best_practices.description: Collect contextual information alongside NPS scores to understand why different user groups provide different ratings
best_practices.do: Ask about user role, experience level, specific use case, and documentation section accessed
best_practices.dont: Don't treat all NPS responses equally without understanding the user context behind the score

best_practices.title: Follow Up with Qualitative Questions
best_practices.description: Use the NPS score as a starting point for deeper conversations about documentation effectiveness
best_practices.do: Ask specific follow-up questions tailored to detractors, passives, and promoters for targeted insights
best_practices.dont: Don't rely solely on numerical scores without understanding the reasoning behind user ratings

best_practices.title: Create Feedback Loops to Content Teams
best_practices.description: Establish clear processes for translating NPS insights into documentation improvements and measuring impact
best_practices.do: Create regular review cycles, assign ownership for low-scoring content, and track improvement trends
best_practices.dont: Don't collect NPS data without clear processes for acting on the feedback and closing the loop with users

best_practices.title: Benchmark Against Documentation-Specific Standards
best_practices.description: Compare NPS scores against other documentation rather than general product NPS benchmarks for realistic expectations
best_practices.do: Research industry-specific documentation NPS ranges and set realistic improvement targets
best_practices.dont: Don't expect documentation NPS to match product NPS scores, as the contexts and user expectations differ significantly

content.docsie_connection:
Modern documentation platforms provide built-in NPS capabilities that integrate seamlessly with content workflows, making it easier for teams to collect and act on user feedback at scale.

  • Embedded Survey Tools: Deploy NPS widgets directly within documentation pages without requiring separate survey platforms or complex integrations
  • Automated Trigger Systems: Set up intelligent survey timing based on user behavior, reading time, or task completion rather than manual deployment
  • Real-time Analytics Dashboards: Monitor NPS trends across different content sections, user segments, and time periods with visual reporting tools
  • Content Performance Integration: Combine NPS data with page analytics, search queries, and user paths to identify improvement opportunities
  • Workflow Automation: Route feedback directly to content owners, create improvement tasks automatically, and track resolution progress
  • Multi-language Survey Support: Collect NPS feedback from global audiences in their preferred languages for more inclusive insights
